column4: If I do a search using aptitude and there is a capital A before the name of the package, does that mean it's already installed?
A means that it's automatically installed as a dependency of some other package. "i" is the generic indicator for installed.
the package i was looking at is build-essential, I heard it is a prerequisite if I want to compile programs with success... Anyone know what I need to do to install it? aptitude install doesn't work
sudo aptitude install build-essential doesn't work?
since it has an A on it, i'm thinking i am suppose to install something else to get it
does it have an "i" next to that "A"?
and no error, just says 0 packages to install and 0 installed
run "apt-cache policy build-essential", copy the output to http://paste.ubuntu.com/, link the page it creates here.
i;m sorry I see it now, says "build-essential is already newest version" and the output of that last file says it is installed
not sure why there is no i when I search it
me either. but hey, problem solved.
yep, thanks so much for the help
should I upgrade my 10.04 to 10.10? or should I wait for official release?
